topic: ISSS Overview – What ISSS Is & What It Does
content:
International Student and Scholar Services (ISSS) provides immigration advising and co-curricular support programming for F-1 and J-1 international students and scholars.

ISSS cultivates a supportive and inclusive community by centralizing immigration advising resources and programming. The office supports students from before departure from their home country through arrival and all the way to graduation and OPT/STEM OPT.

Sections on the website:
- About
- New Students
- Current F-1 Students
- J-1 Exchange Visitors
- Events and Programs
- Resources

Quick Links include: Immigration Policy Updates, Schedule an Appointment, Contact ISSS, ISpartan Hub, Study Tools.

Other offerings include advising appointments (in-person or via Zoom), help with maintaining visa status, employment, and insurance.

The Global Spartan Scholarship provides financial support for new and continuing international students.

Campus statistics shown:
- #3 Top Master’s University hosting international students
- 35,000+ total students
- 2,500+ international students

Events and news sections highlight past events, workshops, cultural activities, and scholarship announcements.

ISSS Director's Welcome

Dear International Students and Scholars,

On behalf of the ISSS team, I welcome you to San Jose State University (SJSU), San Jose, California, and the United States. Thank you for joining our vibrant and diverse community! We commend you on your decision to take steps to continue your education and/or research outside of your home country. You are taking the initial steps in becoming more globally engaged and a global citizen.

Please know that all of us at International Student & Scholar Services (ISSS) are here to support you throughout your time here at SJSU and beyond. Our goal, on a daily basis, is to ensure your success and make certain you are feeling well supported. As such, please don’t hesitate to reach out at any point in time.

We acknowledge and appreciate the diversity of thought, innovativeness, and the cultural enrichment you bring to an already diverse campus. The ISSS team of international educators and I very much look forward to serving your immigration and programming needs and enhancing your experience at SJSU. I hope to meet each and every one of you during your stay here.

Sincerely,
Parinaz Zartoshty, Ed.D.
Senior Director, Global Programs and Services

topic: ISSS Mission, Vision, and Strategic Goals
content:
Mission:
International Student & Scholar Services (ISSS) cultivates a supportive and inclusive community by centralizing immigration advising resources and co-curricular support programming for F-1 and J-1 international students and scholars. ISSS is committed to the success and well-being of SJSU’s international community and strives to enhance the educational and social experiences of students and scholars.

Vision:
SJSU ISSS welcomes, supports, and empowers international students and scholars to thrive academically, professionally, and personally. ISSS is committed to creating an inclusive campus culture and supporting holistic development while contributing to the growth of SJSU’s global community.

Strategic Goals:
Goal #1: Maintain a Student-Centered Approach
- Provide relevant advising, services, and programming to meet the needs of international students, scholars, and recent graduates on OPT/STEM OPT.
- Provide expert immigration knowledge and student-centered guidance.

Goal #2: Foster Campus Internationalization
- Promote global learning and collaborative opportunities for students, scholars, faculty, and staff.

Goal #3: Champion International Student Advocacy & Campus Education
- Advocate for international students through campus engagement and education on issues and policies affecting them.

Goal #4: Commit to Team Development and Success
- Provide training, technology, and tools for staff success.
- Ensure all voices contribute to group decision-making.
- Serve as a model for team performance and collaboration.

Welcome to San José State University! The New Students section provides essential information for beginning studies at SJSU. This page serves as a resource for international students before arrival, during entry to the U.S., and throughout the first weeks on campus.

Students are encouraged to review Pre-Arrival requirements, Post-Arrival steps, Living in San Jose information, housing guidelines, FAQs, immigration document requirements, and more. This site can be revisited at any time as a reference guide for new F-1 and J-1 students.

topic: Pre-Arrival Requirements – Visa Interview and Documents
content:
After acceptance, students must prepare for their arrival at SJSU. Several steps should be completed before traveling to the United States.

### Visa Interview
All international students must apply for and receive an F-1 visa before entering the U.S. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement provides an overview of the F-1 visa application process at: Student Steps: How to Navigate the U.S. Immigration System.

### SEVIS Fee
Before attending the F-1 visa interview, an online SEVIS fee payment of $350 is required. Students should print and keep a copy of the SEVIS fee receipt for permanent records.

### Required Documents for the Visa Interview:
- Passport
- Form I-20
- SJSU acceptance letter
- Proof of financial support
- SEVIS fee receipt

### Visa Interview Expectations
The interview is typically brief (often under 10 minutes) and conducted in English. If denied, students should request the denial reason in writing and ask for a list of any required additional documents.

Students must clearly communicate their intention to return to their home country following completion of their studies.

More details about the visa process can be found on the Department of Homeland Security’s “Study in the States” website.

### Mock Interview Resources
SJSU provides:
- Mock F-1 Visa Interview videos
- Lists of common interview questions
- Additional links explaining what to expect during the visa interview

topic: Post-Arrival Requirements – First Weeks at SJSU
content:
Your first weeks at SJSU will be busy as you navigate orientations, registration, and settling into housing. Follow these steps to stay on track.

### Clear All Account Holds Before Orientation
Students must log in to MySJSU regularly to monitor updates, messages, holds, and to-do items. ISSS sends immigration check-in instructions via MySJSU. All holds must be cleared before class registration during orientation.

### Attend Campus Orientation & Global Spartan Welcome
All international students must complete two orientation components:
1. Campus Orientation (Frosh, Transfer, or Graduate)
2. Global Spartan Welcome (international-specific)

Exchange students are automatically registered for Global Spartan Welcome and do not need to attend a campus orientation program.

### Get Your Tower ID Card
Tower Cards are issued at the Cashier’s Office in the Student Services Center. Students must present a passport or another photo ID. Undergraduates attending Sparta Camp may receive cards at orientation check-in if their photos were submitted on time.

More details: Bursar's Office → Tower Card page and FAQs.

topic: Living in San Jose – What to Bring
content:
San Jose weather is warm in the afternoon and cooler in the evenings. Students should prepare for temperature changes.

### Recommended Items to Pack:
- Clothing: T-shirts, shirts, pants, jeans, shorts, sweatshirts, skirts, dresses, cardigans
- Comfortable walking shoes (campus is 154 acres with 50+ major buildings)
- Toiletries
- Electronics adapter for 120V U.S. outlets

A video resource is provided: 'SJSU Students Speak About What to Bring'.

topic: Living in San Jose – Transportation, Safety, Groceries, Banks, Phones
content:
### Public Transportation
Students should visit the Transportation Solutions Office to obtain an Associated Students SmartPass Clipper Card. This provides unlimited rides on VTA buses and Light Rail lines. The office also offers information about regional public transportation, including BART and Caltrain.

Trip planning resources:
- 511.org
- vta.org/trip-planner

### E-Scooters & Bikes
Ford GoBike, Bird, and Lime scooters operate around downtown San Jose. Users must download the app. Scooters cannot be ridden on campus; fines may apply.

### Ride Shares
Lyft and Uber are available. Discounts for SJSU students are sometimes offered.

### Parking
Students driving to campus may use:
- South Garage
- West Garage
- North Garage

Parking permit fees and maps: Parking Services website.

### Security Resources
Campus safety measures include bluelight emergency phones and SJSU’s Safe Ride Program (7:30 p.m. – 1:00 a.m.), offering free shuttle rides within a defined perimeter. UPD provides security support.

### Grocery Stores near SJSU
- Grocery Outlet – E. Santa Clara & 7th St (3 min walk)
- Trader Joe’s – 635 Coleman Ave (8 min drive)
- Mi Pueblo – 515 McLaughlin Ave (5 min drive)

### Drugstores
- CVS – 821 The Alameda (7 min drive)
- Target – 533 Coleman Ave (7 min drive)
- Walmart – 777 Story Rd (7 min drive)

### Restaurants Nearby
San Pedro Square, Punjab Café, Tandoori Fusion Grill, Tofoo Com Chay (vegetarian), Ike’s Sandwiches, La Victoria Taqueria, Thai Chili Express, Spoon Fish Poke, Banh Mi Oven.

### Bank Information
ATMs on campus: Chase, Wells Fargo, Bank of the West, Bank of America, US Bank. A US Bank branch is located in the Student Union.

Provident Credit Union (official partner) provides accounts without requiring an SSN. Students must bring their I-94, Passport, and SJSU ID.

Nearby bank branches include:
- Bank of America – 99 S. 4th St
- Bank of the West – 50 W. San Fernando
- Chase Bank – multiple locations
- Wells Fargo – Park Center Plaza

### International Payments via Flywire
Flywire offers strong foreign exchange rates, home-currency payment options, and tracking service for international tuition payments. Students from India can use:
- Flywire Student Forex Card (prepaid debit card)
- Flywire Bank Transfer (LRS form required)

### Currency Exchange
Students may exchange currency at airports or banks; recommended to have some USD before arrival.

### Cell Phone Carriers
Major U.S. carriers include AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, and Sprint. Downtown locations:
- T-Mobile – 100 E San Fernando St
- Verizon – 66 W Santa Clara St

### Driver’s License (California)
Students must be in the U.S. for at least 10 days before applying. Required documents include:
- Passport
- I-94 printout
- I-20
- Two proofs of residency (lease, bills)

Appointments highly recommended. Website: dmv.ca.gov

### Medical Assistance & Student Wellness
The SJSU Student Health Center provides primary care, immunizations, pharmacy access. The Wellness Center offers nutrition classes, violence prevention education, and stress-relief activities.

### Recreation
The SJSU Recreation and Aquatic Center (SRAC) is included in tuition fees. Website: spartanrecreation.com

### Student Service Center Resources
Offices include:
- Registrar (transcripts, enrollment, grade changes, residency, graduation, reinstatement)
- Bursar (fees, payment plans, Tower Card)
- GAPE (graduate evaluations, transfer credits, candidacy)

The center is located on the 1st floor of the 10th Street Parking Garage.

International students must maintain valid immigration documents throughout their studies at SJSU. Students are responsible for keeping documents updated, unexpired, and in compliance with federal regulations.

### Required Documents for All F-1 Students
- **Valid Passport** – must remain valid at least 6 months into the future.
- **Form I-20** – issued by SJSU; contains program dates, major, SEVIS ID.
- **I-94 Arrival Record** – electronic arrival/departure record retrieved from https://i94.cbp.dhs.gov.
- **F-1 Visa Stamp** – required for entry to the U.S. (not required if transferring schools within U.S.).

### Keep Digital & Physical Copies
Students should keep:
- Physical folder with originals
- Scanned digital copies saved securely (cloud + USB)

### Customs Inspection at U.S. Port of Entry
Officers may request:
- Passport
- F-1 visa
- Original I-20
- SEVIS receipt
- Evidence of financial support

Students should be prepared to answer:
- Purpose of entry (“to study at San José State University”)
- Intended major
- Funding sources

### Automated Passport Control
Most students will use automated kiosks at major airports but may still be referred for secondary inspection.

### Important Note
The visa stamp does NOT determine how long a student can stay inside the U.S. Duration of stay is controlled by the I-20 program dates and maintenance of status.

The Form I-20 "Certificate of Eligibility for Nonimmigrant Student Status" is issued by SJSU to confirm admission and eligibility for F-1 status.

### Key Sections on the I-20
- **SEVIS ID Number** – begins with 'N'; unique to each student.
- **Program of Study** – degree level and major.
- **Program Start and End Dates** – students must arrive no earlier than 30 days before the start date.
- **Financials** – documentation of estimated expenses and proof of funding.
- **School Information** – SJSU’s SEVIS school code and DSO signatures.

### Student Responsibilities
- Verify all details immediately upon receiving the I-20.
- Sign and date the I-20 on page one.
- Keep all I-20s ever issued (including old ones).

### Transferring to SJSU (SEVIS Transfer)
Students already studying in the U.S. need a new SJSU I-20. Requirements:
- Maintain full-time status at current school.
- Request current school to release SEVIS record to SJSU.
- Receive transfer-pending I-20.

### Travel Signature
Located on page 2 of the I-20.
- Valid **one year** for enrolled students.
- Valid **six months** for students on OPT.

Students must plan ahead during peak travel seasons.

topic: Immigration Document Details – U.S. Visa Stamp
content:
The U.S. visa stamp is placed in the passport by a U.S. Consulate and authorizes a student to request entry into the United States in F-1 status.

### Important Facts
- A valid visa is required for **entry**, not for remaining in the U.S.
- Visa validity can be single-entry or multiple-entry.
- Visa expiration date does **not** determine how long a student can stay in the U.S.

### Visa Renewal
Students outside the U.S. with expired visas must:
- Schedule a visa renewal appointment
- Present financial documents
- Present updated I-20 with valid travel signature

### Visa Denials
A written explanation from the consulate should be requested. Students may reapply after addressing the concerns.

### Visa Interview Tips
- Answer clearly and honestly
- Be prepared to show intent to return home after completing the degree
- Present ties to home country

The I-94 record is the official document confirming a student’s admission to the U.S. in F-1 status.

### Accessing the I-94
Students retrieve the electronic I-94 at: https://i94.cbp.dhs.gov

### What the I-94 Shows
- Date of entry
- Class of admission (F-1)
- 'D/S' notation (Duration of Status)
- Admission number

### Issues with I-94 Records
Occasionally, the system may:
- Not show a record
- Show incorrect dates or status

If any issue occurs, students must:
- Return to the Port of Entry office OR
- Contact CBP Deferred Inspection Site immediately

### Printed Copy
Students should print the I-94 and keep it with their passport and I-20 at all times for future immigration benefits (SSN, driver’s license, employment, OPT).

All international students must maintain a valid passport at all times while in the United States.

### Validity Requirements
- Passport must be valid **at least 6 months into the future**.
- Renewal must occur before it expires.

### Renewal
Students should contact their home country’s consulate or embassy in the U.S. to renew passports. Processing times vary widely.

### Loss or Theft
Students must:
- File a police report
- Contact home country consulate for replacement
- Inform ISSS if document replacement will affect visa or travel

### Travel Considerations
Students cannot enter the U.S. with an expired passport, even with a valid visa stamp.

### Storage
Keep the passport in a secure location. Avoid carrying it unless necessary.

topic: Housing Overview for New International Students
content:
SJSU offers multiple on-campus housing options and provides guidance for students seeking off-campus housing in San José.

### On-Campus Housing Options
- **University Housing Services (UHS)** manages freshman and upper-division housing.
- Types of housing include:
  - Traditional residence halls
  - Apartment-style units
  - Suites and themed housing communities

### Benefits of On-Campus Housing
- Walking distance to classes
- Furnished units
- Meal plans available
- Peer community support
- Secure and monitored facilities

### How to Apply
- Students must submit:
  - Housing Intent application
  - Initial payment if required
  - Proof of enrollment
- Application portal: https://www.sjsu.edu/housing

### Early Move-In
Available for international students depending on arrival dates and ISSS orientation. Additional fees may apply.

### Housing Contracts
- Contracts are legally binding.
- Cancellation fees may apply.
- Students should carefully review the terms before signing.

### Accessibility & Special Accommodations
Provided through Accessible Education Center (AEC). Students must submit requests early.

### Important Reminder
On-campus housing fills quickly. Students should apply as soon as the application opens.

topic: Off-Campus Housing Guide for SJSU Students
content:
San José offers a wide range of off-campus housing options, including apartments, shared rooms, homestays, and private rentals. ISSS provides guidance for navigating the rental market.

### Common Off-Campus Housing Types
- Studio apartments
- 1–2 bedroom apartments
- Shared rooms in student houses
- Private room rentals

### Recommended Search Platforms
- **SJSU Off-Campus Housing Website**: https://offcampushousing.sjsu.edu
- Zillow
- Apartments.com
- Facebook groups (use caution)

### Lease Considerations
Students should understand:
- Lease term (usually 12 months)
- Security deposits
- Utilities included or excluded
- Move-in fees
- Pet policies

### Roommates
Students often share apartments to reduce costs. They should discuss:
- Cleaning responsibilities
- Quiet hours
- Utility sharing

### Scams Warning
Common red flags:
- Asking for payment before viewing
- Listings with no photos
- Unusually low rent prices
- Pressure to sign immediately

### Transportation
Consider proximity to VTA bus routes, light rail, or SJSU campus.

### Safety Tips
- Visit the neighborhood during daytime and nighttime
- Confirm locks and security measures
- Ask landlord for maintenance history

topic: Temporary Housing for Newly Arriving Students
content:
Students arriving in San José before securing permanent housing may need short-term accommodations.

### Short-Term Housing Options
- Hotels near SJSU (range from budget to mid-tier)
- Hostels and shared accommodations
- Extended-stay hotels with weekly rates
- Airbnb or private rentals

### Recommendations by ISSS
- Students should book temporary housing early during peak arrival months (July–August, December–January).

### Cost Considerations
Typical nightly rates in San José:
- Budget options: $75–100
- Standard hotels: $120–160
- Extended stay: varies by duration

### Location Considerations
Stay within:
- Downtown San José
- Areas with reliable public transportation

### Safety Tips
- Avoid sharing personal documents with hosts
- Verify identity and reviews before booking

### Useful Links (text references)
- SJSU Housing Resources: https://www.sjsu.edu/housing
- ISSS housing recommendations page

topic: Housing FAQ for New International Students
content:
Frequently asked questions regarding housing for new international students.

### FAQ Topics

#### 1. Should I live on or off campus?
- On-campus: convenient, furnished, community support.
- Off-campus: more independence, flexible pricing, variety.

#### 2. Is there family housing?
- Limited availability. Students with dependents should contact University Housing directly.

#### 3. Can I arrive before housing contracts begin?
- Early move-in may be available for international students for an additional fee.

#### 4. How do I find roommates?
- SJSU roommate finder tools
- Off-campus housing website
- Orientation groups

#### 5. How far from campus do most students live?
- Many live within 1–3 miles.
- Popular areas include downtown SJ, Japantown, Rose Garden, Spartan Village.

#### 6. What are average rental costs?
- Shared room: $700–$1,000
- Single room: $1,000–$1,400
- Studio/1BHK: $1,700–$2,300

#### 7. Are utility costs included?
- Depends on the lease. Students must clarify before signing.

#### 8. Are there ISSS-approved landlords?
- No. ISSS does not endorse specific landlords. Students must research independently.

#### 9. What documents do landlords typically require?
- Passport and visa
- I-20
- Proof of funds
- Co-signer information (sometimes required)

San José is located in Silicon Valley and offers diverse cultural, academic, and recreational opportunities.

### Key Facts About San José
- Third-largest city in California
- Known for technology companies, startups, and innovation
- Mediterranean climate with mild winters and warm summers

### Transportation
- **VTA Bus & Light Rail** – discounted passes for students
- **BART** – connects to San Francisco and East Bay
- **Caltrain** – commuter rail to Peninsula and SF
- **Biking & Scooters** – available around the city

### Weather
- Average 300 sunny days per year
- Winter: 50–60°F
- Summer: 80–95°F

### Cost of Living
San José has one of the highest living costs in the U.S.
- Rent is largest expense
- Utilities and groceries higher than national average

### Safety Tips
- Avoid walking alone late at night
- Keep valuables secure
- Use well-lit streets

### Food & Culture
- Large Asian, Indian, Vietnamese, Mexican, Middle Eastern communities
- Numerous grocery stores catering to international cuisines

### Recreation
- Parks, hiking trails, museums, concerts, sports events
- Nearby cities: San Francisco, Santa Cruz, Palo Alto

International students should open a U.S. bank account soon after arriving to manage finances, pay tuition, and receive refunds.

### Why Open a U.S. Bank Account?
- Easier to pay rent, tuition, and bills
- Ability to receive direct deposits (on-campus jobs)
- Avoid international transaction fees

### Common Accounts
- **Checking Account** – used for daily transactions, debit card usage
- **Savings Account** – used for storing funds, earning small interest

### Banks Popular with SJSU Students
- Bank of America
- Chase Bank
- Wells Fargo
- US Bank
- Credit unions (e.g., KeyPoint, Star One)

### Required Documents to Open an Account
- Passport
- I-20
- I-94 arrival record
- SJSU Admission Letter
- Local address

### Tips When Opening an Account
- Ask about student or "new to U.S." accounts with no monthly fees
- Avoid overdraft features unless necessary
- Enable fraud alerts

### Digital Banking
Most banks provide mobile apps for:
- Bill pay
- Money transfer (Zelle)
- Mobile check deposit

### International Transfers
Students may use:
- Remitly
- Wise
- Bank wire transfers

Processing times and fees vary.

topic: Phone Plans & SIM Cards for International Students
content:
Students should obtain a U.S.-based phone number as soon as possible for campus verification, banking, and communication.

### Major Mobile Carriers
- **AT&T**
- **T-Mobile**
- **Verizon**

### Prepaid & Student-Friendly Options
- Mint Mobile
- Google Fi
- Visible (by Verizon)
- Metro by T-Mobile

These providers often have affordable plans, no contracts, and eSIM support.

### Required Documents
- Passport
- U.S. phone-compatible device
- Address for billing

### Plan Types
- Unlimited talk/text plans
- Limited or unlimited data plans
- International calling add-ons

### SIM vs eSIM
- eSIM activation available for most modern smartphones
- Faster activation for new arrivals

### Tips
- Compare coverage in San José
- Avoid long-term contracts
- Consider group/family plans with roommates for discounts

topic: Transportation in San José & Bay Area
content:
San José offers several public transportation options for students traveling to campus, grocery stores, or exploring the Bay Area.

### Key Transit Systems
- **VTA (Valley Transportation Authority)** – local buses and light rail
- **BART** – regional rail connecting San José to the East Bay & San Francisco
- **Caltrain** – commuter rail connecting San José to Peninsula and SF

### Student Discounts
SJSU provides discounted VTA passes for eligible students.
- Check TSU or SJSU Transportation Services
- Digital pass available on mobile apps

### Getting Around
- Biking & scooters available in downtown SJ
- Rideshare (Uber, Lyft)
- Car rentals for day trips (Zipcar available on/near campus)

### Airport Access
- **San José Mineta International Airport (SJC)** – closest airport
- **SFO** and **OAK** accessible via BART + Caltrain combinations

### Safety Tips
- Keep belongings close while riding transit
- Travel in well-lit areas at night
- Follow posted rules and respect transit staff

All international students (F-1/J-1) enrolled at SJSU are required to maintain university-approved health insurance.

### Mandatory Coverage
International students are automatically enrolled in SJSU's insurance plan each semester.
Coverage typically includes:
- Doctor visits
- Hospitalization
- Emergency services
- Mental health counseling
- Prescription medications

### Waivers
Students may request a waiver only if their alternate insurance meets strict U.S. and California requirements.
- Waiver deadlines apply each semester
- Proof of comparable coverage required

### Using Your Insurance
Students receive an insurance card via email or online portal.
Use it for:
- Medical appointments
- Pharmacy visits
- Emergency care

### Student Health Center
Located on campus; provides:
- Primary care
- Vaccinations
- Sexual health services
- Mental health counseling
Some services may incur small fees even with insurance.

### Emergency vs Urgent Care
- **Emergency Room** – life-threatening issues
- **Urgent Care** – non-life-threatening issues that need quick attention

Students should check copay and deductible details before seeking care.

New students must meet the CSU immunization requirements before enrolling in classes. Failure to provide proof may result in registration holds.

### Required Vaccinations
- **MMR** – Measles, Mumps, Rubella
- **Varicella (Chickenpox)**
- **Tdap** – Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis
- **Meningococcal** (for students under 22)

### Recommended Vaccinations
- Influenza (seasonal)
- COVID-19 vaccines/boosters (depending on current guidelines)

### TB Screening (for high-risk groups)
Some international students must complete a TB risk assessment or TB test.

### How to Submit Records
- Upload to SJSU Student Health Portal (text reference)
- Submit clear copies of vaccination cards or physician records

### Deadlines
- Must be completed before course registration

### Common Issues
- Missing dates
- Unreadable documents
- Records not in English
Students should request official translations if needed.

Visa Interview
Prior to entering the United States, you are required to apply for and receive an F-1 visa. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement outlines the process of F-1 visa application at the following website; Student Steps: How to Navigate the US Immigration System. Before attending your visa interview, an online SEVIS fee payment of $350.00 is required. Please print and maintain a copy of this payment receipt in your permanent records.
You should take the following documents to your visa interview:
Passport
I-20
SJSU acceptance letter
Proof of financial support

More Information
Expect the visa interview to be very brief, (less than 10 minutes) and to be conducted in English. If you are denied the visa, please request the reason you were denied in writing, along with a list of the documents they require to obtain approval. It is important to clearly communicate that you intend to leave the U.S. after completion of your studies. You can learn more about the visa application process at the Department of Homeland Security’s Study in the States website.

Your first few weeks at SJSU will be busy and action-packed. Here are some reminders to keep you on track while you are navigating orientation, course registration and settling in to your new housing.
Things to do once you arrive at SJSU
Clear All Account Holds Before Campus Orientation
Your MySJSU account is your primary portal for accessing updates and information. By logging into your account, you can view messages from various departments, holds and pending items on your to-do list. ISSS will be sending you messages regarding your immigration check-in via MySJSU, so make sure that you keep checking your account on a regular basis. In order to register for classes during campus orientation, you will need to remove all holds.
Below are some common holds placed on a student’s account:

Attend Campus Orientation & Global Spartan Welcome
By now, you should have already registered for a campus orientation program (frosh, transfer, graduate) and a Global Spartan Welcome program for international students. Attendance at both programs is required.
If you are an Exchange student, you are automatically registered for the Global Spartan Welcome, and you are not required to attend a campus orientation program.
Get Your Tower ID Card
The Tower Card is your SJSU ID Card. Tower Cards are available at the Cashier's Officelocated in the Student Services Center. You will be required to show one form of photo ID, such as your passport or driver’s license. For more information, see theBursar's Office Tower Card page and the Tower Card list of frequently asked questions.
Undergraduates attending Sparta Camp of the Spartan Experience for Transfers can pick up their Tower Card at orientation check-in if you submit a photo electronically by the deadline. Look for an email from the Bursar’s Office for details.

Living in San Jose
What to bring
San Jose is hot in the afternoons and cooler in the evenings. We recommend that you bring enough layers with you so that you’re prepared for shifting temperatures throughout the day. Here are some items that you may want to pack:
T-shirts, shirts, pants, jeans, shorts, sweatshirts, skirts, dresses, cardigan
Comfortable walking shoes- Our campus is over 154 acres with over 50 major buildings. You will want to bring shoes that can hold up to your multi-day orientation.
Toiletries
Adapter- If you are bringing electronics from your home country, you will need an adapter that converts to 120 V.
SJSU Students Speak About What to Bring
Public Transportation
There are many ways to get around campus and the downtown area. For public transportation, please visit the TransportationSolutionsOffice to obtain a Associated Students SmartPass Clipper Card. The card will allow you to have unlimited rides on VTA buses and Light Rail Lines. The office can also provide information on regional travel outside of San Jose as well as information on regional public transcription such as BART and Caltrain. You can also refer to the following sites for help with planning your trips:
511.org
vta.org/trip-planner
E-Scooters and Bikes
For a fun way to get around downtown San Jose, you can try using a Ford GoBike, Bird, or Lime Scooters which can be found around campus. Before you ride, you will need to download the app. You will be charged for unlocking the scooter and for each minute of your ride. Please be aware that you can’t ride the scooter on campus. If you are caught or reported, you are likely to incur a fine by the University.
Ride Shares
Another transportation option is using a rideshare app such as Lyft or Uber. Throughout the year, these apps will periodically promote discounts to SJSU students for rides around certain distance from campus, so be on the look-out for special deals!
Parking
If you plan to drive to campus with your own car, there are 3 main garages you can use, which includes the South Garage, West Garage and North Garage. Please refer to this map for more information. For more information about your parking permit fees, please visit Parking Services.
Security
SJSU is committed to ensuring your safety. All across campus, you will find bluelight phones, which you can use to report an emergency or request an escort during the day or night. Also, during the evening from 7:30 p.m to 1:00 a.m, you can take advantage of SJSU’s Safe Ride Program which is a shuttle service that will provide a ride to all SJSU students within a specified perimeter. For all other aspects of campus safety, you can contact the UPD’s office.

topic: Maintaining F-1 Status, Enrollment Requirements, Course Types, Exceptions
content:
Maintaining F-1 Status
Review the following options for maintaining your F-1 Status
Enrollment Requirements
Post-Completion OPT
STEM OPT
Exceptions to Full-Time Enrollment
Other Resources

Enrollment Requirements
Pursue a full course of study (i.e., 12 units for UGRD and 9 units for GRAD).
Unless authorized by ISSS for
Reduced Course Load
Concurrent Enrollment
Culminating Experience
Be mindful of allowable online credits. Only one course or 3 units per a student's full-time enrollment can be online. The other remaining courses must be in-person or hybrid.
If you only have one course to complete in your final semester, this course cannot be online.
Make progress towards degree completion.
Maintain a valid I-20.
Know your expiration date.
Extend in a timely manner.
Shorten - if finishing degree program earlier than expected.
Update if major changes.
Maintain a valid travel signature.
Validity of 12 months, when pursuing degree.
Validity of 6 months when on OPT/STEM OPT.
Report a change of address within 10 days of moving via MySJSU.
Do not engage in off-campus employment (paid or unpaid) without the proper employment authorization (i.e., CPT).

Course Types
Requirements

In-person
You are required to meet regularly with a faculty member to complete the course requirements and attend lectures or other in-person interactive activities.

Hybrid
You are required to meet both in-person and online. The majority of course work may take place online, but students may be required to complete specific projects, tests, or orientations on the physical campus. This includes courses that require only a one-time meeting with a faculty member. Hybrid courses can be counted toward your F-1 full-time enrollment requirements as in-person courses.

Online
You are required to complete all course requirements, lectures, or other activities online. There are no required in-person meetings. A maximum of one online course or 3 units per semester can be counted towards your F-1 full-time enrollment requirement. However, this does not account for extra units for more than 12 units for undergraduates and 9 units for graduates.

Exceptions to Full-Time Enrollment
Reduced Course Load
Concurrent Enrollment
Culminating Experience
Other Resources
Traveling
Leave of Absence
Final Semester and Year
Changing Degree Level at SJSU
Transferring In/Out

topic: Post-Completion OPT and STEM OPT Requirements
content:
Post-Completion OPT
Work within the dates of the authorized (EAD) Employment Authorization Document.
All employment (paid or unpaid) must be related to your major field of study.
Employment must be at least 20 hours per week, in order not to accrue unemployment days.
Do not exceed an aggregate of 90 days of unemployment.
Report employment via the SEVP portal or directly to ISSS within 10 days.
Report a change of address within 10 days of moving via the SEVP portal.
Maintain a valid travel signature.
Validity of 6 months, when on OPT.

STEM OPT
All employment must be for an e-verified employer, related to your major field of study, paid, and at least 20 hours per week.
Report employment and changes in employment within 10 days of the change, via the STEM OPT Employment Update e-form.
Reporting requirements at the following times: 6 months, 12 months, 18 months, 24 months.
Maintain a valid travel signature.
Validity of 6 months, when on STEM OPT.
Do not exceed 150 days of unemployment, applied to the entire period of standard Post-completion and STEM OPT.

Change of Address
As an F-1 student, you must regularly report any address changes to a Designated School Official (DSO) to ensure that your information is correct in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS). Federal regulations require that you report a change of address within 10 days of moving.
In MySJSU, the address type of SEVIS D is used for F-1 students to report your new residential (physical) address to SEVIS. Please follow the instructions below.

If you are currently enrolled at SJSU and have not yet graduated:
Access MySJSU in one.SJSU and find the Personal Information section
Click “Add a new address” to find SEVIS D
Update your U.S. residential (physical) address in SEVIS D within 10 days of moving
(You may keep a different U.S. mailing address in Mail, but the address in SEVIS D must be where you live.)

If you have graduated from SJSU and are on OPT or STEM OPT:
Please update your address directly in the SEVP Portal. If you do not have access to the SEVP Portal, please complete the SEVP Portal Access Form.
While you are participating in OPT or STEM OPT, you will need to update your address within 10 days of the change in the SEVP Portal instead of MySJSU.

Changing Degree Level at SJSU
If you have completed a Bachelor’s degree at SJSU and have been admitted to a Master’s degree program at SJSU, you will need to complete the Change of Education Level I-20 Request e-form and submit it to ISSS. After you have submitted your eform, ISSS will create a new I-20 for you and email you when your “Change of Education Level” I-20 is ready. Please note the following:
If there is more than 5 months between the last date of your attendance or OPT/STEM OPT end date and the start date of your new degree, you may not be eligible for a “Change of Education Level” I-20. Please contact ISSS before submitting your request eform. For updated information on SJSU semester start dates, please refer to the SJSU Registrar's Office.
You may request to obtain your “Change of Education Level” I-20 before the last date of your employment on OPT/STEM OPT, however, you must stop your employment the day before the semester start date of your new degree.
"Change of Education Level" I-20 does not require a travel signature on the second page in order for you to be able to enter the U.S. You receive a "Continued Attendance" I-20 with a travel signature only after you are enrolled and have completed the new student immigration check-in.

Culminating Experience
What is a culminating experience?
A culminating experience is required for the completion of a master's or doctorate degree program. It is the final requirement to culminate your degree.
As an F-1 graduate student, you need to enroll in a minimum of 9 units each term to maintain your immigration status. However, you may qualify for a full-time exception, if you are not in your final semester of study while you are enrolled in your culminating experience course. A full-time exception allows you to maintain your F-1 status as a full-time student.
You are permitted to complete your Masters Project/Thesis Proposal course, Comprehensive Exam, or Creative Work along with your other courses in the same semester.

How to File the ISSS Culminating Experience Form
1) Consult with your academic advisor to determine whether you are qualified for a full-time exception.
2) Complete the Culminating Experience Confirmation - F-1 Students Only e-form.
For the fall semester, we start accepting these requests in iSpartan on July 15th.
For the spring semester, we start accepting these requests in iSpartan on November 15th.
3) Once your department approves your request, our office will be notified. We will review the form and inform you if your request has been approved.

Concurrent Enrollment
To maintain full-time status, F-1 students can enroll at another institution concurrently*. Per F-1 regulations, a full-time course load is a minimum of 12 units total for undergraduate students, and a minimum of 9 units total for graduate students. Of this minimum, ONLY one course (3-4 units) of online coursework may be counted towards the full-time enrollment.
You MUST be enrolled in at least 6 units at SJSU.
You will need to fill out the Concurrent Enrollment Request form and submit it to the ISSS office along with proof of your enrollment at the other school.
The course(s) must be at least 6 weeks in duration.
You must submit an unofficial transcript to ISSS upon completion.

Add Dependent(s) in F-2 Status
A student in F-1 status is able to add either their spouse/partner and/or their unmarried child, under the age of 21, as a dependent in F-2 status.
Application Steps
Fill out and submit the Dependent F-2 I-20 Request e-form via the iSpartan Hub.
Upload documents: marriage certificate (for spouse) or birth certificate (for child). If not in English, upload original + certified translation.
Financial Documentation
You will need to show an additional $5,000 per dependent.
Processing time is 5–7 business days.

Ending My F-1 Status
Reasons you may end your F-1 status:
- Approved for new immigration status
- Leaving U.S. to finish degree abroad
- Ending OPT/STEM OPT earlier
- Withdrawing or taking leave from SJSU
- Graduating and departing U.S.

Do NOT end F-1 status if you plan to:
- Work on OPT
- Change education level at SJSU
- Transfer SEVIS record

How to end your status:
Submit “End My F-1 Status” request to ISSS.
Once approved, your SEVIS record ends.

Future return to U.S. in F-1 status:
You must apply for a new Initial I-20 and new SEVIS ID.
May need to pay new SEVIS fee + apply for new visa.

Impact on CPT/OPT:
After ending F-1, you must complete 2 full-time semesters again before eligibility.

Final Semester
2 Semesters Out:
Meet academic advisor.
Determine enrollment + RCL needs.
Apply for graduation.
Plan post-graduation options.

1 Semester Out:
Submit Final Semester RCL.
Final course cannot be online.
Attend OPT workshop.
Extend I-20 if needed.
Choose final plan:
- New degree at SJSU
- Transfer SEVIS
- OPT
- Depart U.S.
Meet ISSS advisor if needed.

I-20 Extension
An international student must extend before expiration.
Valid reasons:
- Change of major
- Research problems
- Documented medical issues
Must be in valid status, making normal progress, and have finances.
Invalid reasons:
- Extra non-required classes
- Delaying graduation
- Incompletes

How to Apply:
Meet academic department.
Meet ISSS advisor.
Submit I-20 Extension Request with:
- Reason
- Financial documents
- Declaration of Finance
Processing time: 5–7 business days.

topic: Leave of Absence & Returning to SJSU
content:
Leave of Absence
Consult ISSS + academic advisor.
Submit ISSS Leave of Absence Request.
Authorized early withdrawal allows 15-day grace period.

Returning (Less Than 5 Months):
Email ISSS 2–3 months before return.
Provide departure + return dates.
Submit Return from LOA Request.
Must check in with ISSS within 1 week of arrival.

Returning (More Than 5 Months):
Must receive new I-20.
Provide finances + passport + LOA Request.
Processing: 2–3 weeks.
Must pay SEVIS fee + get new visa.
Record must be term activated to register.
Attend Global Spartan Welcome.

Reduced Course Load (RCL)
Full-time enrollment required unless approved.
Submit RCL by last day to add classes.
Dropping below full-time without approval violates status.

RCL Reasons:
Academic Difficulty (first semester only)
Improper Course Level Placement
Final Semester RCL
Medical RCL

Medical RCL requires:
Letter from U.S. doctor/psychologist
Exact term, reason, signature, license number

Unit Rules:
Must be in at least 6 units at SJSU.
Only 3 units can be online.
Final course cannot be online.

Travel and Re-Entry to the United States
CBP may inspect documents + electronic devices.
Avoid non-essential travel.

Re-entry Documents:
Passport (valid 6+ months)
F-1 visa
I-20 with travel signature (under 1 year old; 6 months if on OPT)
Recommended: Transcript, financial proof, receipts, SEVIS fee receipt

Travel Signatures:
Complete Travel Signature Request.
Processing: 2–3 business days.

Students on OPT:
Carry EAD card + employment letter.

Visa Renewal:
Only needed if traveling outside U.S.
Interview documents include passport, I-20, SEVIS fee, financial proof, transcript.

Temporary Admission (I-515A):
Issued if documents incomplete. Must be resolved within 30 days.

Typical Inspection Questions:
Purpose of visit, where studying, funding, residence, duration, post-graduation plans.

On Campus Employment
On-Campus means the student is working physically on SJSU’s campus and is earning a paycheck from SJSU. Students in F-1 status can work on-campus up to 20 hours per week during the semester. For graduate students, there are some exceptions to the 20 hours-per-week rule. Be sure to check in the hiring department to see if you are eligible to work above 20 hours per week on-campus. During summer/winter breaks students can work on-campus full-time, provided they are eligible and enrolled for the upcoming semester.

All on-campus jobs require employment authorization (in the form of I-20 with approved work authorization), except for jobs in Dining Services, Spartan Bookstore, or other third-party vendors on campus.

F-1 students are not eligible for Work Study positions. Students who are eligible for Work Study will have it noted in their Financial Aid Award letter.

Please review the full list of details on On-Campus Employment.

Curricular Practical Training (CPT)
Curricular Practical Training (CPT) is an off-campus work authorization for internship experiences or employment which is necessary for program completion. SJSU students can do CPT throughout the year if they meet the CPT eligibility requirements. Please read the CPT policy below in order to maintain your lawful F-1 status.

What is CPT?
CPT is for employment which is an integral part of an established curriculum. CPT employment must directly relate to your major field of study and is only available while students are in F-1 status and enrolled. A student can be authorized to do CPT on a semester basis. CPT employment authorization is written on Page 2 of your I-20.

CPT is approved for a specific employer, location, time frame (start and end dates), and number of hours per week. CPT authorization is required each semester. Students can do CPT part-time of 20 hours or less per week or full-time of 21 hours or more per week. Students must stop working on the end date of their authorized CPT.

Please note, employment may not begin until the CPT is approved and properly noted on Page 2 of your I-20. If you do work without CPT authorization, then you will be in violation of your F-1 student status.

CPT Eligibility Requirements:
In order to do CPT, students must:
• Complete one academic year (one-year enrollment requirement) and be in valid F-1 status.
• Have an eligible F-1 visa status requiring full-time enrollment.
• Have a job offer that is directly related to your field of study.
• Enroll in one credit of internship, academic training, co-op, or practicum class for the semester in which the internship occurs.
• Be in good academic standing.
• Meet the departmental internship course requirements.

Limitations of CPT:
If you do 12 months or more of full-time CPT you will lose your eligibility for OPT. Pre-completion OPT has different rules and may be used in place of full-time CPT depending on your situation.

CPT Application Procedures:
1. Obtain an internship offer letter from your prospective employer.
2. Enroll in the departmental internship course for the term of the internship.
3. Submit the CPT I-20 Request to ISSS through the employment portal.
4. Submit the CPT Agreement Form signed by employer and department.

ISSS will review your application. Processing times vary and students should not begin working until receiving the updated I-20 with CPT authorization on page 2.

Failure to follow the CPT application procedures or working prior to authorization may result in a violation of F-1 status.

topic: Employer Guide for Hiring International Students
content:
Employer Guide
Students in F-1 status are eligible for practical training opportunities off-campus once specific eligibility requirements are met. The two main types of employment authorizations available for F-1 students are Curricular Practical Training (CPT) and Optional Practical Training (OPT). These employment authorizations allow international students to work legally in the United States.

Employers hiring F-1 students for internships or full-time roles should be aware of the following:

CPT (Curricular Practical Training):
• Allows students to engage in off-campus internships while enrolled in an academic program.
• Authorization is granted by the university’s ISSS office.
• CPT is employer-specific.
• Students can work part-time (20 hours a week or less) or full-time (over 20 hours).
• Students must obtain authorization prior to beginning employment.

OPT (Optional Practical Training):
• Post-completion OPT gives students up to 12 months of work authorization after graduating.
• STEM majors may be eligible for an additional 24-month STEM OPT Extension.
• OPT is not employer-specific, so students can work for any employer in their field of study.
• Authorization is granted by USCIS, not the university.

I-9 & E-Verify:
• F-1 students on CPT or OPT may complete the I-9 process.
• For STEM OPT, employers must be enrolled in E-Verify.

Employer Responsibilities:
• Provide a training opportunity directly related to the student’s major.
• Sign the required training or evaluation forms.
• Follow federal regulations concerning employment of noncitizens.

Hiring F-1 students can help employers access highly skilled, multilingual, globally experienced talent with strong academic backgrounds.

Pre Completion OPT
Optional Practical Training (OPT) is employment authorization that allows students to gain practical experience in their field of study. Pre-Completion OPT takes place before a student's program end date.

Pre-Completion OPT Details:
• Students may apply for Pre-Completion OPT while still enrolled in their degree program.
• Employment must be directly related to the student’s major.
• Students may work part-time (20 hours or less) while school is in session.
• Students may work full-time during official university breaks or after completing all course requirements except the thesis or culminating experience.

Eligibility Requirements:
• Must be in valid F-1 status.
• Must have completed one academic year.
• Must not have used more than 12 months of full-time OPT previously.

Application Process:
1. Submit the OPT I-20 Request through the ISSS employment portal.
2. Receive an updated I-20 with OPT recommendation.
3. Submit Form I-765 and required documents to USCIS.
4. Wait for Employment Authorization Document (EAD) approval before starting work.

Important Notes:
• Pre-Completion OPT is deducted from the 12-month total OPT allocation.
• USCIS processing time can take several months.
• Students must report employment information while on Pre-Completion OPT.

Failure to comply with OPT rules may result in a violation of F-1 status.

Post Completion OPT
Optional Practical Training (OPT) is temporary employment authorization that allows F-1 students to gain practical experience in their major field of study. Post-Completion OPT is available after a student has completed their degree requirements.

Post-Completion OPT Details:
• Students may apply for 12 months of OPT upon program completion.
• Employment must be directly related to the student’s major.
• Students may work part-time (20 hours or less) or full-time (more than 20 hours).
• Students must not accrue more than 90 days of unemployment.

Eligibility Requirements:
• Must be in valid F-1 status.
• Must have completed one academic year.
• Must have completed all degree requirements.
• Must not have used more than 12 months of full-time OPT previously.

Application Process:
1. Submit the OPT I-20 Request to ISSS through the employment portal.
2. Receive an updated I-20 with OPT recommendation.
3. File Form I-765 with USCIS.
4. Receive the Employment Authorization Document (EAD).
5. Begin working only on or after the EAD start date.

Important Notes:
• USCIS processing times can be several months.
• STEM majors may be eligible for a 24-month STEM OPT Extension.
• Students must complete required reporting while on OPT.
• Students should keep their employment information updated to avoid violating status.

Students interested in Post-Completion OPT should review all requirements carefully before applying.

Economic Hardship
F-1 students who experience severe economic hardship due to unforeseen circumstances may be eligible to apply for off-campus employment authorization.

Economic Hardship Details:
• Authorization is granted by USCIS, not the university.
• Students may work up to 20 hours per week while school is in session and full-time during breaks.
• Employment does not need to be related to the student’s major.
• Students may not begin working until receiving the EAD.

Eligibility Requirements:
• Must have been in F-1 status for one academic year.
• Must demonstrate severe, unforeseen economic need.
• Must be in good academic standing.
• Must show that on-campus employment opportunities are insufficient.

Examples of Unforeseen Circumstances:
• Substantial changes in currency value or exchange rate.
• Loss of financial support.
• Unexpected increases in tuition or living costs.
• Medical expenses.
• Natural disasters or crises in the student’s home country.

Application Process:
1. Submit Economic Hardship I-20 Request to ISSS.
2. Receive I-20 with recommendation for Economic Hardship.
3. File Form I-765 with USCIS.
4. Await approval and receive EAD.

Economic Hardship employment authorization is temporary and must be renewed if needed.
[No content was provided in the user's paste. Placeholder document created per instruction 1A.]

SEVP Portal
The SEVP Portal allows F-1 students on OPT or STEM OPT to update their personal and employment information as required by federal regulations.

Student Responsibilities in the SEVP Portal:
• Update employer name and address.
• Update residential address.
• Report changes in employment.
• Ensure all information is accurate within 10 days of any change.

Accessing the Portal:
• Students receive a portal activation email from SEVP after OPT approval.
• The email contains a unique link to create a password.
• Students must use the same email they used for their I-765.

Troubleshooting:
• If the activation link expires, students may request a reset via ISSS.
• Students should check spam/junk folders for the activation email.
• Portal errors may require assistance from ISSS or SEVP.

Important Notes:
• The SEVP Portal is separate from MySJSU.
• Students on STEM OPT must complete Form I-983 and cannot solely rely on the SEVP Portal for reporting.
• Failure to update portal information may lead to termination of SEVIS record.

Students should use the SEVP portal carefully and review all entries for accuracy.

24 Month STEM Extension
The 24-Month STEM OPT Extension allows eligible F-1 students who completed a degree in a qualifying STEM field to apply for an additional 24 months of employment authorization beyond the initial 12 months of Post-Completion OPT.

STEM OPT Details:
• Employment must be directly related to the student’s STEM degree.
• Students must work at least 20 hours per week.
• Employer must be enrolled in E-Verify.
• Students must complete and submit Form I-983 (Training Plan) with their employer.
• Students must receive regular evaluations and follow the training plan requirements.

Eligibility Requirements:
• Must be currently on Post-Completion OPT.
• Must have earned a degree in a DHS-designated STEM field.
• Employer must be E-Verify registered.
• Must not have exceeded 90 days of unemployment during Post-Completion OPT.

Application Process:
1. Submit the STEM OPT I-20 Request to ISSS.
2. Receive an updated I-20 with STEM OPT recommendation.
3. File Form I-765 with USCIS.
4. Continue employment for up to 180 days while the STEM OPT application is pending.

Important Notes:
• Students cannot be self-employed on STEM OPT.
• Volunteer positions do not qualify.
• Students must report employment and verification checks every 6 months.
• Students must submit annual self-evaluations on Form I-983.

The 24-Month STEM OPT Extension provides additional training time for students to gain practical experience in their STEM field.

STEM OPT Reporting Requirements
Students on the 24-Month STEM OPT Extension must follow specific reporting requirements in order to maintain F-1 status.

Reporting Requirements:
• Report employment information within 10 days of any change.
• Submit validation reports every 6 months.
• Submit an annual self-evaluation (Form I-983).
• Report termination of employment.

6-Month Reporting:
Every 6 months, students must confirm the following:
• Legal name
• Residential address
• Employer name and address
• Continued employment

12-Month and 24-Month Evaluations:
• Students must submit a self-evaluation on Form I-983 at 12 months and again at 24 months.
• Employers must review and sign these evaluations.

Changes That Must Be Reported:
• Employer name change
• Employer address change
• Supervisor change
• Material changes to training plan
• Termination or resignation

Failure to comply with these reporting requirements may result in the termination of the student’s SEVIS record.

Allowable Employment
F-1 students on OPT or STEM OPT must ensure that all employment meets federal eligibility requirements.

Allowed Employment on OPT:
• Paid employment directly related to the student’s major.
• Multiple employers (all must be directly related to major).
• Contract employment.
• Self-employment (allowed only during Post-Completion OPT, not STEM OPT).
• Short-term gigs, project-based work, or agency employment.

Allowed Employment on STEM OPT:
• Must be paid employment.
• Employer must be E-Verify registered.
• Work must be at least 20 hours per week.
• Must follow Form I-983 training plan.
• No self-employment.
• No volunteer or unpaid work.

Students must ensure that all work performed is directly related to their field of study and complies with federal rules to maintain valid immigration status.

topic: Scholarships (Global Spartan Scholarship, Louie Barozzi Scholarship)
content:
Scholarships

International Student & Scholar Services offers scholarships for international students in F-1 status.

Global Spartan Scholarship
Recognizes and provides financial support to new and continuing international undergraduate and graduate students. Applicants must demonstrate:
• Academic excellence
• Leadership
• Commitment to globalization/international education
• Financial need

Louie Barozzi Scholarship: International Students
Recognizes SJSU international students for contributions to the community and commitment to international education and exchange.
Three awards are given annually:
• One international undergraduate student
• One international graduate student
• One Study Abroad & Away participant

Social Security Number and ITIN

What is a Social Security Number?
A Social Security Number (SSN) is required for anyone who has employment in the US. It is used for tax purposes and to report wages. It is a 9-digit number issued by the Social Security Administration and is valid for life.

When can I apply for an SSN?
You may apply once you have employment and a job offer letter.
Scenarios include:
• F-1/J-1 student with on-campus job
• F-1 student with CPT or OPT
• J-1 student with academic training
• J-1 scholar with an SJSU appointment

Requirements:
• Must be physically present in the US
• Must wait 10 days after arriving
• Must wait 2 business days after SEVIS validation
• Must apply no more than 30 days before employment start

Application Steps:
1. Obtain job offer letter
2. Email ISSS the letter – ISSS will issue a support letter
3. Complete SSA Form SS-5
4. Bring job offer letter, ISSS letter, passport, I-94, and completed SS-5 to SSA office

Processing time: 2–4 weeks (estimated).

When can you begin working?
Most employers require SSN before starting work. Check employer policy.

ITIN – Individual Taxpayer Identification Number
Used for tax purposes when someone cannot obtain an SSN.
ITIN is required for:
• Certain nonresidents
• Those receiving taxable non-service scholarships or fellowships
• Those with US-source income but not eligible for SSN

F-1 and J-1 students eligible for SSNs should NOT apply for ITINs.

ITIN Application through ISSS requires verification of:
• Passport bio page
• I-20/DS-2019
• F-1/J-1 visa stamp
• I-94
• Completed W-7
• Completed W-8BEN (if claiming treaty benefits)

ISSS will provide a support letter confirming verification.
For further processing, students may need a locally-based certified agent.

Student Resources

SJSU provides many academic support systems for students struggling with coursework requirements.

Tutoring Help

https://www.sjsu.edu/peerconnections/

Writing Center
https://www.sjsu.edu/writingcenter/

Tax Information

Discounted Access to Sprintax Tax Preparation!
Limited discount codes available. File early to secure a code.

Steps:
1. Register and follow instructions
2. Complete questionnaire
3. Enter unique code: SJSU1500F24
4. Sprintax will prepare your tax return

Who must file taxes?
Anyone in the US on F or J status between Jan 1 – Dec 31, 2024 must file Form 8843.
If you earned taxable US income, you may need:
• Federal tax return (1040NR)
• State tax return (if applicable)

Deadline:
April 15, 2025

Resident vs Nonresident for Tax Purposes:
• Most F/J students are nonresidents for first 5 calendar years (F-1) or 2 calendar years (J-1)
• After that, Substantial Presence Test applies

Open Tax Webinars (Jan–Apr 2025):
Multiple dates provided for general filing information.

Sprintax Nonresident Tax Overview for OPT/CPT:
Covers:
• Residency determination
• FICA exemption
• Pre-employment tax forms

SprintaxTDS Personal:
Helps prepare pre-employment forms like W-4, 8233, W8-BEN.
Cost: $19.95
Includes: residency determination + FICA exemption check

Who must file?
All F-1 students must file taxes each year.
If no income → only Form 8843
If income → 8843 + 1040NR or 1040NR-EZ + CA 540NR

Required documents:
• Passport
• I-20/DS-2019
• SSN/ITIN (if any)
• W-2
• 1042-S
• Travel history
• 1099 (if applicable)
• Do NOT use 1098-T (not valid for nonresidents)

Process:
1. Create Sprintax account
2. Complete questionnaire
3. Sprintax determines residency
4. Generates correct forms
5. Download, print, sign, mail to IRS

Tax Assistance:
• Sprintax support (email + 24/7 live chat)
• VITA/TCE – may not assist with nonresident returns
• Glacier – alternative provider

Disclaimer: ISSS cannot provide tax advice.

Housing for International Students

San José State University offers many housing options for students, ranging from dormitories to apartment-style living and communal housing.

Note: First-time freshmen are required to live on-campus.

University Housing
Provides housing for freshmen, transfer students, and graduate students. Includes:
• Dormitories
• Apartment-style living
• Communal housing

*Meets freshman on-campus requirement.
A campus housing tour for international students is available.

Off-Campus Housing
Finding housing in the Bay Area can be challenging. Students must be cautious of:
• Scams
• Unsafe situations

Temporary Housing
For students who need short-term housing upon arrival:
• Airbnb
• Local hotels (university provides list)

Homestay
Live with an American family for cultural immersion. Managed by:
• International Student Placements (ISP)

International House (I-House)
A residence for 70 U.S. and international students.
Provides:
• Community
• Leadership opportunities
• Group activities
• Travel

*Meets freshman on-campus requirement.

Immigration Policy Updates

Changes to immigration policy can be stressful, and ISSS provides guidance as updates occur.
Information may change, and users should verify details independently.
A central SJSU immigration resources page is available.

Recent Updates:

DoS Issues F, M, J Visa Applicant Social Media Vetting Cable and Authorizes Resumption of Visa Appointment Scheduling
June 20, 2025
• DoS announced new guidance on social media vetting.
• Consulates will resume scheduling F, M, and J visa appointments.

Executive Order: Travel Ban Impacting 19 Countries
June 5, 2025
A presidential proclamation created:
• Full travel ban on 12 countries: Afghanistan, Burma, Chad, Republic of Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Haiti, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Yemen
• Partial travel ban on 7 countries: Burundi, Cuba, Laos, Sierra Leone, South Sudan, Venezuela, Zimbabwe

Temporary Delay in Scheduling New Visa Appointments for F, M, and J Visa Applicants
June 5, 2025
• Temporary pause announced May 27, 2025 for new visa appointments due to expanded social media screenings.

Interview Waiver – Update
February 20, 2025
• Visa interview waiver policy revised.
• Reversed the policy from December 21, 2023.

Executive Order to Combat Anti-Semitism
February 5, 2025
• Executive order issued requiring universities to monitor pro-Palestinian protests.
• For international students, participation could lead to deportation.

Executive Orders Impacting International Community
January 29, 2025
• Multiple executive orders and agency actions affecting international students and scholars.
• NAFSA provides detailed updates.

Travel Guidance for International Students and Scholars
January 13, 2025
• Students are highly recommended to return to the U.S. before January 20, 2025 (Presidential inauguration day).
• Historically, new administrations have enacted restrictive policies on Day 1.

South Africa Travel Ban Revoked
December 31, 2021
• Proclamation 10315 revoked South Africa travel ban.

FAQs – New Students

(Your pasted content for this section did not include actual FAQ text beyond the heading. This entry remains as a placeholder with no additional content.)

Health Insurance

SJSU Health Insurance Requirement
All inbound international students must purchase SJSU health insurance prior to registering for classes.
A registration hold is placed until insurance is purchased.
Holds removed within 48 hours of purchase.

Coverage includes:
• Accidental injury/sickness
• Medical evacuation
• Repatriation

Instructions to Purchase the Health Insurance Plan:
• Insurance provider: United HealthCare Student Resources (UHCSR)
• Administered via Alliant Insurance Services

Steps:
1. Go to UHCSR website
2. Search for 'San Jose State'
3. Select “Medical – High Student Plan Only” → Explore Policy
4. Click “Get Started” → Continue as Guest
5. Select insurance category and fill required info
6. Select semester plan
7. Provide personal info and payment
8. Insurance hold lifted in 24–48 hours

Cancellation / Refund / Exemption Policy

Cancellations (must email ISSS; UHCSR gives final approval)
Valid reasons:
• Not enrolled within first 45 days
• Drafted by military

Refund deadlines:
• Fall 2025: September 15, 2025
• Spring 2026: February 15, 2026

Exemptions allowed for:
• F-1 students with government-sponsored scholarship that includes adequate insurance
• Students covered as dependents by employer-sponsored U.S. insurance (must purchase supplemental evacuation/repatriation)
• J-1 ISEP Exchange participants

How to obtain your insurance ID card:
Electronic only.
Options:
• Through mobile device (uhcsr.com → MyAccount → ID Card)
• Through school-specific UHCSR webpage

When sick:
Refer to instructional infographics provided by ISSS.

Continuation of Tax Information

NEW RESOURCES FOR CPT, POST-OPT, AND STEM OPT RECIPIENTS

As students begin OPT/CPT employment, employers will require tax documents such as W-4 and other pre-employment forms.

Overview of SprintaxTDS Personal:
• Helps prepare correct pre-employment tax forms
• Determines tax residency, FICA exemption, tax treaty eligibility
• Generates W-4, 8233, W8-BEN, and more

Procedure:
1. Register account
2. Complete questionnaire
3. Pay fee
4. Receive generated tax documents → sign → give to employer

User Guide:
• SprintaxTDS Personal manual available for OPT/CPT

Cost:
• $19.95 for form generation
• Tax residency determination and FICA check are free before paying

Note: SprintaxTDS Personal is NOT Sprintax Tax Prep.

Who must file?
• All F-1 students must file each year
• If no income → file Form 8843
• If income → file Federal + State tax returns

Required Federal Forms:
• Form 8843
• Form 1040-NR or 1040-NR-EZ

Required California Forms:
• Form 540-NR or 540-NR-EZ

Download sources:
• IRS website for 8843 and 1040-NR
• California tax website for 540-NR

Assistance Options:
• Glacier
• IRS VITA/TCE (verify if they support nonresident returns)
• Sprintax educational videos and blog

Disclaimer: ISSS cannot assist with tax preparation.

Tax Filing Requirements Summary

Who is required to file?
All F-1 students must file taxes every year, regardless of employment status.

If you did NOT work or receive taxable payments:
• File ONLY Form 8843.

If you DID work or receive taxable payments:
• File Federal Form 8843
• File Federal Form 1040-NR or 1040-NR-EZ
• File California State Form 540-NR or 540-NR-EZ

Where to get forms:
Federal forms:
• Form 1040-NR or 1040-NR-EZ
• Form 8843

California state forms:
• Form 540-NR or 540-NR-EZ

Additional notes:
• Only Nonresident Aliens receive Form 1042-S.
• 1098-T CANNOT be used for nonresident tax returns.
• VITA/TCE programs may not assist nonresidents—call ahead.
• Glacier is an alternative tax software provider for nonresident taxes.

topic: Step-by-Step Guide: Filing Nonresident Tax Forms
content:
Step-by-Step Guide: Filing Nonresident Tax Forms (F and J)

Documents needed for Sprintax:
✔ Passport
✔ Visa/Immigration info, including I-20 or DS-2019
✔ SSN or ITIN (if applicable)
✔ W-2 (if you worked)
✔ 1042-S (if you received scholarship/fellowship income)
✔ 1099 (if applicable)
✔ U.S. entry/exit travel history
✘ 1098-T – NOT used for nonresident returns

Process:
1. Create Sprintax account (link emailed to students)
2. Complete questionnaire
3. Sprintax determines residency status
4. If nonresident → Sprintax prepares Form 8843 + 1040-NR
5. Download and print forms
6. Sign and mail federal returns to IRS
7. If required → file state tax return (Sprintax optionally prepares it for a fee)

If no income:
• Sprintax generates only Form 8843
• Must still be printed, signed, and mailed

Support:
• Sprintax email: hello@sprintax.com
• 24/7 Live Chat
• Sprintax FAQs and educational videos

Disclaimer:
ISSS is NOT permitted to assist with ANY tax form preparation.

SprintaxTDS Personal – Pre-Employment Tax Forms for CPT/OPT

Purpose:
Helps students prepare complex pre-employment tax documents such as:
• W-4
• 8233
• W-8BEN
• FICA exemption calculation
• Tax treaty eligibility

Who can use it?
Any nonresident beginning CPT or OPT employment.

Process:
1. Register account
2. Complete questionnaire
3. Complete payment ($19.95)
4. Sprintax generates correct forms
5. Sign and submit forms to employer

Benefits:
• Ensures correct tax withholding
• Prevents errors on employer onboarding documents
• Avoids FICA over-taxation

Note: This service is DIFFERENT from Sprintax Tax Prep for filing annual returns.

General Tax Help Resources

Software options:
• Sprintax – primary recommended software
• Glacier – alternative for nonresident returns

Live assistance:
• Sprintax 24/7 live chat
• Email support: hello@sprintax.com

Educational support:
• Sprintax YouTube videos
• Sprintax blog (tax guides for nonresidents)

Free/low-cost services:
• IRS VITA/TCE programs (verify if they handle nonresident returns; many do not)

Important:
University staff, including ISSS, legally cannot assist with tax filing.

Tax Responsibilities Reminder

All F-1 students must:
• File Form 8843 every year (even with no income)
• File federal and state tax returns if they earned income
• Keep copies of all forms filed
• Understand that filing taxes is a legal requirement

Important deadlines:
Federal tax filing deadline: April 15, 2025
State tax filing deadline: typically same day

Failure to file taxes may create future immigration complications.

Note on Tax Residency Determination

F-1 and J-1 students are generally nonresidents for:
• FIRST 5 calendar years (F-1)
• FIRST 2 calendar years (J-1)

After this period:
• Substantial Presence Test decides whether you become a 'resident for tax purposes'

If Sprintax determines you are a resident:
• You cannot use Sprintax to file nonresident returns
• You must use resident filing software instead (e.g., TurboTax)

Final University Disclaimer on Taxes

International Student & Scholar Services (ISSS) and all SJSU staff:
• Are NOT allowed to advise on taxes
• Cannot review your tax forms
• Cannot answer detailed IRS questions

All tax decisions must be:
• Confirmed with Sprintax
• Verified with IRS resources or a tax professional
